Australia: Australia's first parliamentary elections was held for the New South Wales Legislative Council (though voting rights are restricted to males of certain wealth or property).
Brazil: Honório Hermeto Carneiro Leão, Marquis of Paraná, becomes de facto first prime minister of the Empire of Brazil. The Emperor Dom Pedro II of Brazil marries Dona Teresa Cristina of the Two Sicilies in a state ceremony in Rio de Janeiro Cathedral.
Chile: University of Chile founded. Fort Bulnes established, the first Chilean presence on the Strait of Magellan.
Cuba: Leopoldo O'Donnell, Duke of Tetuan becomes governor of Cuba 1843–48.
Haiti:
President Boyer is overthrown and flees to Paris in exile
The Constituent Assembly begins formulating the Constitution of 1843; it will take more than three months to finish
The Constitution of 1843 is released and Charles Riviere-Hérard is appointed President of Haiti
Philippine: Francisco de Paula Alcalá de la Torre appointed Governor-General (1843–1844)
Singapore:
Thomas Dunman, the first full-time police chief of Singapore, improves the police force as well as the pay and working hours of policemen.
Singapore became ruled directly from the British East India Company.
William John Butterworth was appointed as the Governor of the Straits Settlements.
Switzerland: The first Schweizerisches Gesangsfest, a singing festival, was held in Zürich.
